choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Secular 

 

  • This kind of pattern can be explained by secular trend.
  • Secular Trends (Long Term Fluctuations): Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal: Seasonal trends (Periodic fluctuations) is seasonal variation/fluctuation in occurrence of a disease. Examples: Measles (early spring), upper respiratory infection (winters), gastrointestinal infection (summer).

 

Option B. Cyclical: Cyclic trend (Periodic fluctuations) is occurrence of a disease in cycles spread over short periods of time, which may be days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Measles (every 2-3 years), Rubella (every 6-9 years), Influenza pandemics (every 10-15 years).

 

Option C. Periodic: Periodic fluctuations include both Seasonal and cyclical trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

To summarize, each of the mentioned criteria - size, symptomatic presentation, and rapid growth - are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms. Thus, the answer is: D. All of the above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Size more than 5.5 cm in males:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that is greater than 5.5 cm in diameter has an increased risk of rupture. The risk of rupture and complications rises significantly as the size of the aneurysm increases. For this reason, surgical intervention is typically recommended when an AAA reaches this size in males.

 

Option B. Patient is experiencing abdominal pain: Abdominal pain can be a sign that the aneurysm is expanding or is about to rupture. If a patient presents with abdominal pain and an AAA, it's often treated as a surgical emergency. The pain might be caused by the aneurysm pressing on surrounding structures or due to impending rupture.

 

Option C. Expansion of >0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA is another indicator of increased rupture risk. An expansion of more than 0.5 cm in 6 months indicates that the aneurysm is growing quickly. Rapid growth can be a sign of structural changes in the aneurysm wall that increase the risk of rupture. Therefore, even if the AAA is smaller than the usual 5.5 cm threshold, if it's growing quickly, surgical intervention is typically considered.

 

Educational Objective:


Abdominal aortic aneurysms require surgical intervention if the size exceeds 5.5 cm in males, the patient presents with abdominal pain, or if there is an expansion of more than 0.5 cm within 6 months.

questions.text: A colonoscopy on an 80-year-old patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions, as shown below. He admitted to using laxatives on a regular basis. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to be the source of this problem? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Senna

 

The given image shows the colonoscopy finding of melanosis coli.

 

The use of stimulant purgatives like Senna , Cascara Sagrada and Bisacodyl can lead to the development of melanosis coli. Also they should not be used for more than 10 days due to the risk of developing atonic colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bran: Bran is a bulk-forming laxative that increases stool bulk and promotes regular bowel movements. It does not cause melanosis coli.

 

Option B. Psyllium: Psyllium is another bulk-forming laxative that absorbs water into the stool, making it easier to pass. It does not lead to melanosis coli.

 

Option D. Methylcellulose: Methylcellulose is a bulk-forming fiber laxative that works by absorbing water and increasing stool bulk. It is not associated with melanosis coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic use of stimulant laxatives like Senna can lead to melanosis coli, characterized by brownish-black pigmentation of the colonic mucosa seen on colonoscopy.

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, who is feeding adequately, thirsty, and exhibits skin that returns to normal after a pinch within 2 seconds? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours. 

 

  • According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has some dehydration and comes under Plan B. The amount of ORS given is 75ml/kg body weight.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 9-month-old baby showing signs of some dehydration due to diarrhea, it is crucial to administer 400-700 ml of ORS over the first four hours, adhering to IMNCI guidelines. This approach ensures effective initial rehydration and sets the stage for ongoing recovery and feeding.

questions.text:
Which of the provided options align with the depicted equivalence margin graph? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

 

  1. ‘A’ represents superiority of new treatment
  2. ‘I’ represents Inferiority of new treatment
  3. ‘E’ represents Non-inferior treatment
  4. ‘C’ is inconclusive
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2 and 3 

 

There are three types of comparators in Randomised Control Trials:

 

1. Superiority Trial – New drug is Better than old drug

 

2. Non-Inferiority Trial – New drug as good as old drug

 

3. Equivalence – New drug same as old drug

 

 

Other Option:

 

4. 'C' is inconclusive: This statement is incorrect as per the image. 'C' represents a superior treatment, as it falls well into the "new treatment better" region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In equivalence margin graphs for RCTs, 'A' can indicate a superior treatment, 'I' an inferior treatment, and 'E' a non-inferior treatment. 'C' does not represent an inconclusive result; it represents superiority.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) High LDL

 

High LDL: This is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines. While high LDL cholesterol is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease, it is not part of the metabolic syndrome criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertriglyceridemia: Elevated triglyceride levels are a criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicate dyslipidemia.

 

Option C. Central Obesity: Defined by waist circumference, this is a key criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicates visceral fat accumulation.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the criteria for metabolic syndrome, reflecting its association with increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: At what BMI value is considered 'fatal' for men? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) <13 

 

  • A body mass index (BMI) of less than 13 in men is considered critically low and potentially fatal. 
  • This threshold indicates extreme undernutrition and can lead to severe health complications, potentially resulting in life-threatening conditions due to vital organ function impairment and failure. 
  • BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women, and values significantly below normal can indicate serious health risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 13 or lower is deemed fatal for males. Nonetheless, females can endure with a BMI as low as 11 or even lower.

choices.text: Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic
Surgical repair on the next elective list
Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel

questions.text: An asymptomatic patient presents with a reducible hernia below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following is the most appropriate management to consider? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Surgical repair on the next elective list

 

Explanation:

 

A femoral hernia occurs below the inguinal ligament through the femoral ring. While this patient's hernia is currently asymptomatic and reducible, femoral hernias have rigid boundaries (femoral vein laterally, inguinal ligament superiorly, pubic arc inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially), creating a high risk for strangulation. Femoral hernias warrant prompt elective surgical intervention regardless of symptoms, as they have a significantly higher risk of complications compared to other hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic - Incorrect because femoral hernias have a significantly higher risk of strangulation (approximately 50% present as emergencies). Unlike some inguinal hernias, femoral hernias should not be managed conservatively, even when asymptomatic.

 

Option C. Emergency surgical repair of hernia - Incorrect because the hernia is currently reducible and asymptomatic, not requiring immediate emergency surgery. Emergency surgery is indicated for irreducible, obstructed, or strangulated hernias.

 

Option D. Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel - Incorrect for the same reason as option C. Additionally, bowel exploration would only be necessary if strangulation was suspected, which isn't the case in this reducible, asymptomatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

All femoral hernias should be repaired surgically on an elective basis due to their high risk of strangulation, even when asymptomatic and reducible.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of thromboangitis obliterans except:(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absence of popliteal pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Thromboangitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) classically presents with a triad of symptoms including intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. Buerger's disease typically affects small and medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery rather than the popliteal artery itself. The disease primarily affects young male smokers under 40 years of age. The popliteal pulse is usually preserved in Buerger's disease, as the pathology affects more distal vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raynaud's phenomenon - This is part of the classic triad of Buerger's disease, characterized by cyclical color changes in digits upon exposure to cold, stress, or vibratory tools due to vasospasm.

 

Option B. Claudication of extremities - Intermittent claudication is a core feature of Buerger's disease and part of the classic triad.

 

Option D. Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis - This is another component of the classic triad of Buerger's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Buerger's disease (thromboangitis obliterans) typically affects small to medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery, presenting with the classic triad of intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon, while preserving more proximal pulses such as the popliteal pulse.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Case control study

 

The cross-product ratio is a measure of association between two categorical variables, and it can be arrived at from a case-control study.

 

In a case-control study, the odds ratio (OR) is often used as a measure of association between the exposure and the outcome. The cross-product ratio is an alternative measure of association that can be derived from the odds ratio.

 

Interpretation

 

OR> 1 → Association Present

OR =1 → No Association

OR< 1 → Inverse/Negative Association → RF is protective(beneficial)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: This type of study examines the associations between exposure and outcomes at the population or group level, not at the individual level, and does not typically use the cross-product ratio.

 

Option B. Cohort study: This type of study follows a group of exposed and non-exposed individuals over time to observe the incidence of outcomes. It uses relative risk rather than the cross-product ratio.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: This study observes a population at a single point in time, assessing both exposure and outcome simultaneously. It can measure prevalence but not the cross-product ratio specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: What constitutes the primary administrative unit in India? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) District

 

  • The principal unit of administration in India is the district, which is administered by a Collector.
  • The district is the basic unit of administration in India and is responsible for implementing various government schemes and programs at the grassroots level. It is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for maintaining law and order, revenue administration, and developmental activities in the district.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tehsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • According to 2023 data, there are 766 districts in India

 

Educational Objective:

 

The district serves as the principal administrative unit in India, playing a vital role in governance and implementation of government policies at the grassroots level.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for diagnosing suspected lateral sinus thrombosis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laugier’s Sign

 

Explanation:

 

Laugier's sign is not used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is actually a sign associated with fracture of the zygomatic arch, where tenderness is elicited on pressing the fractured fragments. This sign has no relationship to lateral sinus thrombosis or any other otological condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Queckenstedt's Test: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis diagnosis. Also called the Tobey-Ayer test, it involves compression of the jugular vein while monitoring CSF pressure via lumbar puncture. In lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side's jugular vein causes no change in CSF pressure, while compression of the normal side increases CSF pressure.

 

Option B. Crowe-Beck Test: This is correctly used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is an alternative to Queckenstedt's test that avoids lumbar puncture. It involves observing retinal vein engorgement through fundoscopy during jugular compression. With lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side causes no retinal vein engorgement, while compression of the normal side does.

 

Option C. Griesinger's Sign: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis. It refers to edema and tenderness over the mastoid emissary vein (posterior to the mastoid process), which occurs due to thrombophlebitis extending from the lateral sinus to the emissary vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While Queckenstedt's test, Crowe-Beck test, and Griesinger's sign are all valid diagnostic indicators for lateral sinus thrombosis, Laugier's sign is unrelated and specifically associated with zygomatic arch fractures.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: An inguinal hernia with acute appendicitis occurring in the sac is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amyand’s Hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically defined as an inguinal hernia where the content is the appendix. When the appendix becomes inflamed within the hernia sac, it represents a case of acute appendicitis occurring within an Amyand's hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Richter's Hernia: This occurs when only part of the bowel wall circumference is the content of the hernia. It typically doesn't present with intestinal obstruction but can directly progress to strangulation.
  • Option B. Littre's Hernia: This is defined as a hernia where the content is Meckel's diverticulum, not the appendix.
  • Option D. Maydl's Hernia: This refers to a double loop of intestine within the hernia sac.

 

Named Hernias at a glance:

  1. Omentocele - Content is omentum
  2. Enterocele - Content is intestine
  3. Richter's - Part of bowel wall circumference is in the sac
  4. Littre's - Content is Meckel's diverticulum
  5. Maydl's - Double loop of intestine
  6. Amyand's - Content is appendix
  7. Sliding hernia - Organs like cecum (right) or sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and form a part of the wall of the sac

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically an inguinal hernia containing the appendix, regardless of whether the appendix is inflamed or normal.

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Sternal end

 

Explanation:

 

The sternal (medial) end of the clavicle is the ossification center used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage. This is a critical ossification center for age estimation in the late teens and early twenties. The secondary center at the medial end of the clavicle appears at around 18 years of age and fuses with the shaft by 21-22 years of age in males (slightly earlier in females).

 

In the context of legal consent to marriage, which typically requires individuals to be at least 18 years for females and 21 years for males in many jurisdictions, the fusion status of the medial end of the clavicle provides valuable evidence for age determination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromial end (Incorrect) The acromial (lateral) end of the clavicle is not commonly used for age determination related to legal consent for marriage as it fuses earlier and doesn't provide relevant age information for the late teens to early twenties.

 

Option C. Shaft (Incorrect) The shaft (body) of the clavicle is the primary ossification center that appears very early (around 5-6 weeks of intrauterine life) and is the first bone to begin ossification. It doesn't provide useful information for age estimation in the context of marriage consent.

 

Option D. Tubercle (Incorrect) The tubercle of the clavicle doesn't have a separate ossification center that would be relevant for age determination in the context of legal consent for marriage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial (sternal) end of the clavicle is a key marker for age estimation between 18-22 years, making it highly valuable for legal age determination in marriage consent cases.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

choices.text: FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.text: You work as a medical officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC). You are tasked with developing a strategy to address widespread anemia in the community. Considering the need for efficacy, safety, and ease of administration, which of the following options would you recommend for the prevention and treatment of anemia in this setting? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

 

  • Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 is likely to be the best mass prophylaxis against anemia.
  • Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance.
  • Supplementing vitamin B12 can reduce incidence and prevalence of megaloblastic anemia as cost factor is not that significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose: It is not yet evident to be more efficacious than FeSO4

 

Option C. Ferrous fumarate: It is considered to be equally efficacious but vitamin C as an adjunct improves absorption.

 

Option D. Injection iron sucrose: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is a first-line option. It is only indicated if the oral form is not tolerated or patient is not compliant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

 

The image shows dilated column of veins in the veins suggestive of esophageal varices. They are seen in portal hypertension and present with hematemesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrett’s esophagus: Characterised by salmon coloured tongue like patches at GE junction

 

 

Option C. Gastric erosions: Lesions seen in stomach due to H. Pylori.

 

 

 

Option D. Esophageal candida: Appear as milky/curdy white patches.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.
